problem:
How many integers are common solutions to these three inequalities? \[
\begin{array}{cccc}
(1) & -3y & \geq & y+7 \\
(2) & -2y & \leq & 12 \\
(3) & -4y & \geq & 2y+17
\end{array}
\]
chatgpt_solution:
We solve each inequality separately.

For the first inequality, we have $-3y \geq y+7$. Adding $3y$ to both sides gives $0 \geq 4y+7$. Subtracting 7 from both sides gives $-7 \geq 4y$. Dividing both sides by 4 gives $-\dfrac{7}{4} \geq y$. Since $y$ must be an integer, the possible values of $y$ are $-\dfrac{7}{4}$, $-2$, $-1$, 0, 1, 2, $\ldots$. However, since we must also have $-\dfrac{7}{4} \geq y$, we conclude that the only possible values of $y$ are $-\dfrac{7}{4}$, $-2$, $-1$, and 0. These 4 values work, so there are $\boxed{4}$ solutions to this inequality.

For the second inequality, we have $-2y \leq 12$. Dividing both sides by $-2$ gives $y \geq -6$. Since $y$ must be an integer, the possible values of $y$ are $-6$, $-5$, $-4$, $\ldots$. However, since we must also have $y \geq -6$, we conclude that the only possible values of $y$ are $-6$, $-5$, $-4$, $\ldots$, 0, 1, 2, $\ldots$. There are infinitely many solutions to this inequality.

For the third inequality, we have $-4y \geq 2y+17$. Adding $4y$ to both sides gives $0 \geq 6y+17$. Subtracting 17 from both sides gives $-17 \geq 6y$. Dividing both sides by 6 gives $-\dfrac{17}{6} \geq y$. Since $y$ must be an integer, the possible values of $y$ are $-\dfrac{17}{6}$, $-3$, $-2$, $-1$, 0, 1, $\ldots$. However, since we must also have $-\dfrac{17}{6} \geq y$, we conclude that the only possible values of $y$ are $-\dfrac{17}{6}$, $-3$, $-2$, $-1$, and 0. These 5 values work, so there are $\boxed{5}$ solutions to this inequality.

To find the solutions that are common to all three inequalities, we must find the values that satisfy all three inequalities. The values that work must satisfy $-\dfrac{7}{4} \geq y$, $y \geq -6$, and $-\dfrac{17}{6} \geq y$. The only value that satisfies all three inequalities is $y = \boxed{-2}$.
